Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2010 05:17AM jenny66 wrote: dear texas, i know and you're right, it isn't fair, and denial is normal.  i think everyone here goes in and out of it.  it actually helps protect us during hard times.  it sounds like you are a bit more positive since reading the posts, and i'm glad.  remember to come back often and know we are here for you. love and hugs, jenny

Posts.Title: Good news Diana63 clemson93

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 11:32AM jenny66 wrote: dear dantow, since i posted and didn't have the name of the treatment i was trying to think of, i did find out what it was: "Selective Internal Radiation Therapy (SIRT), which injects microscopic radioactive beads directly to the liver tumor through the hepatic artery. The outpatient procedure provides a concentrated dosage over a longer period of time, while conserving normal liver tissue that surrounds the tumor. That means minimal side effects." tami boehmer., july 13, 2010. i found this on tami boehmer's site and she too has breast ca with liver mets.  i'm including a link to her page that is really helpful for all cancer survivor's.  she wrote a new book about it, and it sounds amazing. www.tamiboehmer.com/ here's the link. i hope this helps you an others, as i do have a friend that is going to be getting this treatment.  she is trying to get approval from her insurance company now.  she's had stage IV with mets for 5 years and her name is robin farley.  you can also find her blog online by googling her name.  she's an amazing person too!
Posts.Title: surviving high liver involvement? dantow pee

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 01:29PM jenny66 wrote: hi dantow, i just happened to read your post and my heart goes out to you.  there are many women on here with advanced liver mets and i have a friend who has had it for 5 years.  she just failed her last tx too, and now is applying to her ins. company to do some kind of targetted ablation with a radioactive laser.  she has mult. liver mets too, and her liver enzymes are also elevated.  i'm hoping someone that's been on here longer will share some insight with you.  how is she feeling?  how are you?  this is a place where you will find lots of hope and wonderful support, so please check in.  i'm sure by tonight others with reply. big hugs, jenny
Posts.Title: surviving high liver involvement? dantow pee

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 05:48AM jenny66 wrote: jenn, i read your second post and am so glad you got to talk to him.  you sound soooo much better.  this is just a bump in the road, i'm hoping, so i'll be watching to see when you post again with what you are going to do.  i've had my tumor markers going up too, so i'm right there with you.  scared.  of course you didn't do anything wrong.  i think we all go through that same scenario in our minds, quesitoning, needing to understand "why".  that's human nature.  i, for one, still don't have my answer.  i'm just adding my support, and hoping you know that whatever the future holds, you are not alone.  love and hugs, jenny

Posts.Title: Pain meds the good bad and ugly mohonda mohonda

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 08:34AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:58AM by jenny66 my gutt is dead from the scoliosis, and i have this problem BAD.  i'm also watching for anything that helps.  i already take senekot, prune juice, amitiza, lactulose, and even this doesn't work for me.  the nerves are dead, and my option now is an ileostomy, which i dread.  n-e-way....if anyone has any STRONG suggestions, please post.  it's miserable!  now with some of the new meds, it's even worse.  potty woes for me. at times i wonder if it's not mets there as well?  sigh..... welcome to cancer land.
Posts.Title: Bowel Blues bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: jenny66 wrote: i have not been able to sleep since my life has been turned upside down by what i've learned.  any help and support is appreciated, as i truly feel as if i am losing it.  i originally came here last week after learning i have breast cancer, and thinking i would be fine.  or so my oncologist told me.  he said "you are not going to die from this, jenny", thinking it was confined only to the breast.  i told him about the strange reaction i've had from meds lately, after just going through a complicated hysterectomy, with multiple infections, and left hip pain.  i have severe, progressive scoliosis, and was finally being seen for harrington rod surgery at 49, so i could once again function as a whole person.  he begrudgingly agreed to do a pet scan, warning me that the insurance wouldn't cover their portion.  i had the pet scan on tueday...it's so hard to keep track of all of this in my mind at this point...and i got a call from the oncologists lpn telling me they had the preliminary results.  she was incredibly insensitive and downright rude, considering what she was telling me.  they found a large mass on my left leg, and 2 more on my spine at t12, and l3, and l4.  i have grade 1V mets.  i honestly think it's also in my lungs and liver, based on my recent symptoms.  i honestly feel as if i can't hang on, and that this is a death sentence at this point.  i was an oncology nurse at duke for many many years, treating only stage 1V breast ca patients, all that died while i was with them. this was, however, 10 years ago.  but the memories of all of those brave women, and all they endured, is giving me flash backs to what is to come for me. i have been up almost all night, unable to sleep since learning the news.  i cry, i mourn, and i just cannot wrap my mind around this.  i had a lump a year and a half ago, and have been having mammograms, with several biopsies for almost 20 years.  i've had them for the past 12 years at the same facility, and was told it was just "breast tissue", and sent the little card saying my mammo was the same as the year before.  i delayed getting the one for this year done because i had several surgeries during this time, and just couldn't get better enough to go.  i am alone.  one year and five mos. later, i got called in for an ultrasound, then biopsy, then sent to the oncologist, who assured me i didn't have mets.  why didn't they biopsy when i found the lump the year before, and how could i not have insisted with a very, very strong family history of breast ca?  i feel so stupid, so angry, and just cannot wrap my mind around all that's happened.   i've called several hotlines, hoping for help.  and until i knew i had bone mets, i truly believed there was a cure.  now, i don't know where to go from here, and how to deal with this news.  i go to the oncologist this morning, and the lpn told me palliative care only.  i'm angry at myself and angry at the radiologist who said i was "fine" even with a large lump in my left breast.  mentally, i had just begun to accept the cancer diagnosis only to learn i am already too far gone for any treatments except radiation, or so they say.  i have appointments lined up to see breast surgeons, and plastic surgeons for reconstruction.  i don't know what will happen with that, after reading all of your wonderful posts and learning that if it's this far advanced they often won't remove the primary tumor.  the mets to the spine is severe, and complicates my scoliosis diag. which has been debilitating.   i'm sorry to rant like this, but i am truly "lost", and am searching for a tad of hope right now.  i wish i didn't know all i know from my career, that's for sure.  she wouldn't say if other organs were involved, but  i honestly think it is also in the lungs and liver at the very least.  the lpn said "you knew" as if somehow that made it all ok.  i honestly didn't know.  it's only been since the big surgery and strange symptoms that after i got the cancer news that i wondered.  it's like my worst fears have come true, and i dearly want to hang on to life and find some hope.  i know things have changed since i worked in oncology, and i want to believe there is hope.  i want to find a way to stop the visions i keep having about my own death.  i want to live.   if anyone would be interested in speaking with me it would be greatly appreciated.  there are no stage 1V with bone mets, esp. with leisons this large, i can find from the different groups i've called for help.  i am just lost, and praying i can find others going through similiar things.   please know that i send my best to everyone here, and i apologize if this post is negative.  i am just still in shock.  thank you for posting, so i could find you in my darkest hour.  there must be a "dawn" someplace out there.          3/10 dx'd w/ grade 2, idc, 2 cm. stage IV, mets spine and pelvis, ER/ PR+, HER-2+(6+). here hoping to make true friends and cultivate HOPE. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: losing it jenny66 33skidoo

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2011 10:59AM jenny66 wrote: wow, this is soooo cool.  i wish we could do meetings like this everywhere.  hmmm....*wondering if it's do-able*.  wishing you all a wonderful get together, love and hugs, jennhy
Posts.Title: MICHIGAN GET TOGETHER :) Travelingpants2 Travelingpants2

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 07:45AM jenny66 wrote: thank you sooo much for the support.  i haven't been even back online since writing the first time, for actual fear of finding out negative information.  for those of you who pm'd me, i don't know how to do it, but would love the opportunity to talk further.  again, i hope that my post has not been too negative, and that i haven't brought anyone down with my words.  they are and were just my ramblings and disbelief.  i still feel stuck there as i don't believe that i know what to do next. i started zometa, herceptin, and femara.  the latter, i'm fighting to find ways to help with the costs as my insurance will only cover it up to a certain dollar amount that i'll reach really soon.  i don't know if i qualify for the patient assistance program, as i remember doing many of these applications for my patients.  it's over 500 a month.   i still don't know if i have brain mets.  other than the initial pet scan that i insisted on, i haven't had any further tests.  i am asking for a brain scan, but it hasn't been scheduled yet.  i had a "multi-disciplinary conference" with the same organization that my doctor is a part of, and this is what they said: systemic treatment is most important now, and none of them encouraged me to have breast surgery, as they didn't think it was appropriate, or that i could handle it at this time.  2 of them told me i seemed depressed....no, duh!  i asked for effexor, and was taking only a quarter a day for a few days, but am now taking the full dose and yes, am still very, very overwhelmed by this diagnosis.  i asked about traditional chemo, radiation, and the radiologist, head of the dept. and surgeon all said to try "targeted therapy" first, which yes, are "slow burners" and don't work fast, and they don't do any testing to see if it's working for at least three mos.  (er+ pr+ her2+).  seems like a long time to me.  the cancer on my spine on l3, l4, and t12 are large leisons, larger than the cancer in my breast, and the one on my pelvis is very very large.  the only plan is to continue with the meds i listed, every three weeks, and monitor the tumors after several cycles.  i wish i lived in an area with an major medical center, but i don't and traveling is hard for me.  it makes me want to buy a camper, so i can not only be seen, but to travel for sure!  we do have a teaching hospital but i wonder if it's any better.  they said no surgery, no radiation at this time, which to me doesn't feel like being aggressive enough.  i think they are afraid of litigation, and the director, whom i saw even mentioned it because he knows i requested my records(still don't have them).  the oncologist i have now, just plays down the seriousness of this all, and it seems like they all do, because there is nothing besides cookie cutter treatment that they start with.  that's how it feels to me, at least.  one suggested healing touch therapy.   i talked to a woman who suggested going to the metastatic breast cancer site, so since a few of you have mentioned this, i'm going to check it out.  as for support, it's hard.  i had a woman who is really kind from a local organization go with me for the multi team conference.  they fund the institution i'm going too, with a lot of money each year.  she had stage 2, so it's really hard for her to understand, i think, what this is like.  i truly believe that only those of you who have walked this path understand it, and i am hoping to make contact with someone from on here to talk with.  it's hard for me to be online, because of my back, so it's hard to sit, even short periods of time.  i've had pain from the scoliosis for a long, long time, and finally getting to a place that they were actually going to do something to make it better, and now knowing that won't happen bec. of the new diagnosis is difficult.  the primary tumor is just over 2 centimeters, and just a grade 2.  i don't know how to enter this info as i see many of you have with the diagnosis listed.  to me, that doesn't make sense.  it didn't to the doctors either, i know, because it's not the normal presentation.  i talked to 2 stage 4 survivors, one from the network of hope, and you don't keep in touch with them, and one here locally, who goes to the university for her care.  you're so right....friends don't get it, and i think that's the biggest deficit i have right now is not having support.  i have a room mate for the time being and she totally doesn't get it and is deathly afraid of being around anyone sick.  she avoids even talking to me, or is outwardly angry....nothing in between.  i have grown kids, and one hasn't called at all, one sees it as no big deal and the other, thinks i should do nothing and just wait.  i do have a sister who lives in florida who has helped some, by phone.  yes, all of this makes you want to travel and see things doesn't it?  i thnk about that a lot lately, but money is an issue for sure.   i guess i wanted to at least post again and let everyone know what was going on, say thank you sooo much for your support, and ask for any suggestions on what to do next.  the 2 things i have pending are the brain scan and a port placement.  that's about it.  the zometa, of all things, made me really, really sick. i had a fever of over 103, and wonder if that's normal?  as a nurse, i don't think so.  i did call the oncologist and he assured me it was normal.  ???  i felt soo bad, like everything hurt, and i could actually feel exactly where the tumors are.  strange huh?    i'm going to see if i can add my dx somehow on here, and go back to the posts that said i could pm, and see if i can figure out how to do it.  and yes, i'm still crying....does that ever stop?  i guess it doesn't help having absolutely no estrogen now, and the constant hot flashes and not being able to sleep.  i guess i feel like i just need a friend who really does get this and some good reliable "steps" to take next.   please know that i'm sending healing and loving hope, and energy to each of you who so kindly posted and cared.  this is the only site i found, in my search, with a place for stage IV survivors.  i know i'm still in a fog, and not thinking clearly at this point.  yes, it is like a constant radio on in the room, and it's always there, isn't it?  i hope it gets quieter very soon.  i am one big heart and that is the best description i know to let you all know who i really am.  very emotional, and very caring.   i've spent much of my life trying to do all i can to make this a better world.  i love helping people, and animals especially.  right now, i wish i was tougher.  i think a thicker skin would go a long, long way right now.  know that i'm trying, and please, if anyone is interested in actually talking on the phone, let me know. jenny
Posts.Title: losing it jenny66 33skidoo

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 04:14PM jenny66 wrote: dear cathy, thank you so much for replying.  yes, today has been hard, for sure.  with my other back issues i know i need to get to a major medical center but am not sure how, or even how to start.  i'm going to post a new topic for any suggestions.   yes, alone sums it up pretty well.  no one not in this situation can understand it, and i've learned that early on.  the fact that i have found this site, and that there is some support here helps, though.  thank you. jenny
Posts.Title: losing it jenny66 33skidoo

Posts.Content: May 4, 2010 05:24PM jenny66 wrote: thank you so much for all the support and love here.  it definitely has been the hardest thing i've ever gone through.  there are so few women i have found anyplace locally living with stage IV cancer, and this forum truly helps.  i just read the article in the paper from the woman who has lived 17 years with this, and although 2% is small, i'm praying that the forum sisters i have here will live on, and increase that percentage!
Posts.Title: losing it jenny66 33skidoo

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 03:38AM jenny66 wrote: thank you janis.  i honestly don't know what to do next.  i do want a mastectomy, bilateral, but have been told that it's not an option at this point.  walking is just about impossible with the pain.  i don't know how you managed to get through the early days after diagnosis, and the post, and suggestions are greatly appreciated.  thank you, thank you.  just am truly losing it right now.  i keep thinking this is a bad dream and i'll wake up. jenny

Posts.Content: May 12, 2010 10:08AM jenny66 wrote: thank you to all of you who opened your hearts and wrote, or posted.  thank you claire, for being there for me.  i guess i still haven't gotten my "sea legs" with this diagnosis yet, and i still struggle with it.  the tiredness and pain are tough, but for me, the emotional stuff is harder still. i just had my port put in on last thursday, and currently have a bad rash everywhere.  i'm hoping it's not a reaction to the port, but to the clorohexidine they used.  i go to my primary doc friday, and am taking benadryl and watching it.  the port itself is painful and i wonder, does that get better with time?   sending blessing to each and every one of you who took the time and love to reply.  i don't think i would be able to get up in the mornings not having this support right now.  i want to be there for anyone also needing extra support, so please write if i can help you as well.   claire, you are my rock.  you inspire me.  thank you. jenny

Posts.Title: RobinWendy katie11 Lowrider54

Posts.Content: jenny66 wrote: http://www.knoxvillebreastcenter.com/kim-rowden-fund/hands-on-event.html i posted this a while back under the tennessee thread and under fund raisers i think, and no one read it.  IF YOU LIVE in or close to knoxville tn, usa, this is your time to be pampered.  go to the link for info and call for an appointment at total body works.  you get to chose from haircut, massage, facial, pedicure or manicure and spaces are filling up fast.  it's oct. 4th, from 10-4.  if you want to go, or you want to give to sponsor someone for 60.00, check out the link.  i am working on getting more salons to do this at other times, but so far, the two that said they were interested haven't gotten back to me.  this is something they have done for 6 years, for the kim dowden foundation.  she was a patient where i'm being treated, and she passed at a very young age.  i've met ppl who knew her, and she was amazing.  they set up a time for free spa services for women in breast cancer treatment with this one spa, and they do this every year now.  you don't have to donate to go, as the donations go into a pot for the women who do go....but of course, it's appreciated, and keeps it going.  i was delighted to have found this.  WE NEED SPA AND SALON SERVICES.  can i have an amen'd? haha, you'll get that if you've ever watched madea movies!  ha...great for the soul!.  so...tell anyone you know who can come to the knoxville tn, area on oct. 4th! love and hugs, jenny      3/10 dx'd w/ grade 2, idc, 2 cm. stage IV, mets spine and pelvis, ER/ PR+, HER-2+(6+). here hoping to make true friends and cultivate HOPE. Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 01:34PM jenny66 wrote: they really need to truly educate the public about breast cancer, i think anyway.  it does make it hard when i always get asked, "when do you finish your treatment?", or for those few who do get it, they cry if they were dx at an earlier stage, out of sheer fear of becoming me, or stage IV.  i guess i try to do this myself, since the proverbial "they, and them", aren't personal friends of mine.  i honestly think this will change in years to come, but until then, i try to educate when i can.  i just have a hard time not crying myself when i do it on bad days!  what can you do?  just go on, and try to make things better, and help at least one person.  anyway, i say we do have a voice, and we do MATTER.  love and hugs,  jenny

Posts.Title: 1 year cancerversary flachica flachica

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2010 09:30AM jenny66 wrote: i think since she posted on facebook that most likely she is actually reading this, and i have no doubt she has been to our little family here often, but has just not spoken under her real name.  i am both angry and sad.  i spent last evening watching her prior interview, and reading her statement.  so, elizabeth, you are loved so very much by all of your sisters.  your pain is our pain, your struggle our struggle.  your hope for 8 more years, is our hope for just one sometimes.  i know that you have the best possible health care, and even though when i heard they are stopping treatment, i also know that there comes a point where it just can't be enough.  so...i hope you know that you have meant sooo much to each of us, often without a voice, and largely ignored.  the fact that you brought some understanding to being "stage IV" is HUGE, and we thank you for not hiding it, and for being the first to stand up and say we do exist and we do live however long we can, facing innumerable hardships.  and yet, we endure for as long as we can, as well as we can.  when the time for me comes, and i can only speak for myself, i hope i have as much grace and acceptance as you do.  i have recently had a progression and they are doing nothing for me.  so, i know that this time does come, it's just when.  we all hope for 20 years, like the small few who beat all the odds.  i have no doubt there are many women on here who will still be flourishing 20 years from now.  i also know that it probably won't be me.  but i'm ok with that.  i just pray that someday, SOON, not another sister must die from this disease. YOU ARE LOVED, ELIZABETH, AND YOUR SISTERS ARE WITH YOU.   all of my love and soft gentle hugs, your sister,  jenny

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 08:03AM jenny66 wrote: hi maureen, happened to see your post...i didn't have the primary removed either so i know what the 'wondering" is like.  esp. as a nurse.   the studies do support removing it, and it said that women with it taken out lived 18 mos. longer.  that is a newer study and more are in progress, and the med. community is divided on the "what to do".  there is no agreement btw docs on this.  i often get tired of stage IV women looking at me like i'm crazy when i tell them i didn't have a mx, so i understand.  honestly, i don't think there is a "ONE Size fits all" for this question.  afterall, look at all the recurrances after mx, and aggressive chemo within a few years.  the new stats are that one third dx with breast ca, will dev. mets and stage IV ca.  i was FLOORED by that stat, and i am quoting a woman in new york, who said that's what sloan kettering says??  i'm not sure on this one, really.  i have mixed feelings about it.   i am glad you got to go to moffit, they are sup. to be really, really good, and i would love to go there.  i think i would trust that advice, and put to 'PEACE', your questions, and TRUST the treatment they suggest.  we all have to do that at some point and i've been struggling myself with that recently...sigh. hugs, jenny

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 12:00AM jenny66 wrote: dear jennifer, i am soo happy to see your post.  what a wonderful thing to have happen at this time.  congratulations on the diet too!  when i read it, i cried, ...happy tears.  you ARE beautiful, inside and out, and he is lucky to have you.  i am hoping this is the beginning of something long lasting, fulfilling, and most of all, a love story.   it's been a hard past month on the boards, at least i think so.  we've had much bad news and some terrible losses.  i think we all needed to hear something upbeat like this, so thank you for sharing this part of your life.  you deserve so much to be loved!  this disease challenges us in everyway possible i think, but it also teaches us how strong we really are, and what is really most important in our lives.  in that way, i think we all have the chance to become better people.  yes, i'd rather not have to go through this to get there, but i think it does change us in not only negative ways.  thank you!   i'm hoping sharon posts soon about her "date" adventures...that always makes me feel better too. you sound terrific, and like you are in a really good place right now with the weight loss, and a positive attitude.  thank you, and i hope you post again.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 09:48AM jenny66 wrote: thank you everyone for replying.  i'm not sure what to do, since each of you have had different experiences.  it IS scary not being on anything.  he said that it remains in your system for 3 weeks, and i know they all have a long half life.  i'm wondering if i should just start the arimidex?  it's been 3 days now being off.  i sure don't want to progress more.  so far i've been able to get samples of femara, but those are few and far between now.  it's really expensive and more than i can pay, at almost 500 a month.  i do have the coupon, but it makes me reach my donut hole quicker, as they charge the insurance company what the coupon doesn't pay.  the generic arimidex is waaay cheaper.  just wondering if it does have less side effects, and if i should just start taking it NOW rather than waiting.  bo, that's scary that taking you off for a few mos. led to that much progression.  now i'm really scared!  he said the 2 are identical???  are they?  i really hate this rollar coaster, and at times i feel like i'm hanging bet. this life and the next.  sorry to be so glum.  i'm usually the "cheerleader" for others, and NOW, i can't muster it up to do it for me.  sigh.  anyway, please post any info that may help.  hugs and love to all of you...mjl, bo, and lane.

Posts.Title: stage IV "discrimination"? jenny66 lindaa

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 12:40PM jenny66 wrote: dear jenn, sorry i am late replying...why?  because i have felt the exact same way lately.  i know how you feel. it's especially hard being single at least i think so.  the only thing that helps me is to talk to someone who cares.  for me, that's been my sister, and then i come here.  she is there for me, but doesn't have cancer.  my sisters on here help me, even when i feel too sad to post, i at least read.  i wonder a lot if i'll "go" quickly, i guess a lot because of my other health issues, and i know i'm not strong physically.   i try to make myself strong physically, mentally, and emotionally the best i can, by doing the things i CAN do.  i try not to think about what i can't do anymore, and when it's in my face, because i can't get out with the weakness, and difficulty walking, i watch funny movies, romances....things like that.  i pray a lot.  i try to enjoy nature more.  i guess i just do my best to live in the here and now.  just know you aren't alone, and it does sound like you are feeling a little better.  please post when you feel like this.  i need to do that more myself...it DOES help to take in all the love from the women here. hugs, and love, jenny

Posts.Title: WANTED: STAGE IV FIVE YEAR SURVIVORS! MCTHO eag1954

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 04:17PM jenny66 wrote: hi leah, i'm pretty new here, dx with stage IV from the start to bones also.  I'm on herceptin and femara, and still waiting to see how it goes.  I know that when i first came here and posted i was scared to death, and in many ways am still.  i'm really sorry about your news, but the good thing is it's only in one location in your bones...that makes your prognosis better than with multiple lesions, or so i have read.  my heart goes out to you, and i'll help in anyway i can to support you.  i can tell you that when i first posted, in the middle of the night, under "losing it", i had sooo many wonderful women post back, and some even wrote to me personally.  there are some wonderful people here, and sooo much knowledge.  you sound very positive and that's a wonderful thing.  i hope to hear more from you on how things go.  it looks like you've already had several women post with a similiar med regimine.  you are NOT ALONE, and there are many, many wonderful women on here that will encourage, support and help you.  sending big hugs, and positive thoughts.  i know that you will be NED for a long time to come! jenny
Posts.Title: I'm joining you Leah_S ChocolateLover

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2010 10:28PM jenny66 wrote: ditto to what lisa said...she has been through  A LOT. love and hugs, jenny  please post any info....
Posts.Title: #3 Has anyone heard from CarynRose? jeanne46 Honeybear

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 07:55AM jenny66 wrote: flachica, i wish i knew your real name to write back.  i came on to answer a message and saw your post first thing this morning.  i can sooo relate, and honestly, feel the same right at this moment.  i don't have any advice to share but i know some of the women here will.  i "get it too", and have been in that mind-set myself lately.  the moment when it finally "hits".  i guess i just don't want you to give up because there are things that will most likely work for you too, they just have to find it trial and error.  please don't count yourself "out" just yet.  we don't know how long we have sweetie.  none of us do.  this "ride" does SUCK big time, and  personally, i want OFF, YESTERDAY.  i just want to comfort you, and help you through this time, because i care.  a lot.  remember when we were talking about a support group that actually met?  you know you are welcome to visit here anytime, and so is anyone else interested in meeting.  i would travel but it's just hard for me.  do you have anyone with you?  i just feel like you need a hug, and no, that's not gonna cut it, i know, but you need support just the same.  just know that i'm here, i get it, and you can pm me anytime, ok sweetheart?  i'm older than you, but i do know about the long line of bad things, and now this.  i have a friend here who has just had her liver mets zapped with radiation that cuts them away without actual cutting of the liver.  i mention that bec. i can find out info and let you know about it.  if you look up robin farley online, you'll find her caring bridge page and a way to email her.  she has had liver mets for 5 years, and it progressed, so she did this new treatment.  no, she isn't her+++ like both of us are, but she does get it i think.  she's in her very early 40's.  i know it sucks, but you have people here who understand, and will help you "stand" when  you aren't strong enough.  i'm one of them.  most of my mets are to my spine, and with all my other back issues it is the LAST THING i needed to find out.  i'm sending love chica, and i hope you come back and i hope you pm me or someone.  you are loved.  jenny    ps...it's always ok to RANT here.  i think we ALL need to be able to do that honestly, at some point, to stay sane....

Posts.Title: Liver Mets confirmed - now what? Ezscriiibe BeckyOD

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 10:24AM jenny66 wrote: hi lynn and elizabeth, thanks for replying as i wasn't really sure how to do something like this.  lynn, i am in the southern us, in tn, so not far from you.  elizabeth, what area do you think i should post?  for the same state/city i'm in or more general?   it's my hope that i can not only start a group that i can be a part of but to somehow post in a way that will connect ALL women who want to do something like this in their areas.  any suggestions are really appreciated.  i for one, really do appreciate the help i've gotten here on this site, but i also know that it would be WONDERFUL to actually meet face to face and develop actual friendships with other women in the same situation.  i think with this many members, somehow, it should be possible.  ANYTHING is possible, right?  when i doubt that i think about the woman who has been stage IV for 18 years, and it gives me hope.  i truly believe that if we reach out to one another, and if the desire is there, that it can be done on local levels to actually meet.   anyone who is interested, who has wanted the same thing, or even has any suggestions please post. thank you, and hugs, jenny
